Key Match Events: Nurul Hasan claimed that the on-field umpires missed an incident of 'fake fielding' from Virat Kohli, which could have resulted in five potentially crucial penalty runs for Bangladesh.
The incident took place in the seventh over of Bangladesh's chase at Adelaide Oval when Litton Das played the ball towards the deep off-side field off Axar Patel.
Kohli feigned a shy as the ball was going past him, but the on-field umpires, Marais Erasmus and Chris Brown, didn't take action.
The first flashpoint came in the 16th over of the India innings when Kohli signaled a no-ball towards umpire Erasmus after top-edging a pull towards square leg.
The second incident occurred when the umpires approached Shakib about play resuming following a rain break at the end of the seventh over, at which point Bangladesh was 17 runs ahead on DLS.
Post-Match Reflections: Nurul Hasan mentioned the 'fake fielding' incident while talking to reporters after the game.
BCB cricket operations chairman Jalal Yunus said the 'fake throw' was brought to the umpire's notice but he said he didn't see it.
Shakib Al Hasan spoke extensively to Erasmus during and after the match.
Shakib told the umpires repeatedly that the ground could get dry if they took a bit more time, but the umpire's decision was final.
Miscellaneous Highlights: Cricket's Law 41.5 prohibits deliberate distraction, deception, or obstruction of the batter, and if breached, the umpire can declare the delivery as a dead ball and award the batting side five runs.
The ruling on 'fake fielding' needs to be made by the umpires in real time and is about the attempt to deceive the batters rather than them actually being deceived.
